moves.1. e4 e5: We move our king's pawns to free our queens and kingside bishops...
moves.2... Nf6: ...and I develop my knight to attack his pawn...
moves.3... Kxf7: ...and I remove his bishop, with the knight there as a shield from the queen.
moves.4. d3: He moves his queen's pawn to cover its neighbour...
moves.5. Qf3: ...and he brings up his queen, from with my king is shielded by my knight...
moves.5... d5: ...so now I contest the centre with my queen's pawn.
moves.7... Qd4: ...allowing me to bring up my queen...
moves.8. c3 Qxe4+: ...and perform a royal fork on a square controlled by my knight...
moves.12. Rh2: ...but he moves it out of harm's way.
moves.12... Nc6: So now it's the cue for me to bring up my other knight...
moves.14... Ne4+: ...allows me to fork the king and knight...
moves.16. Ne2 Rad8: Now I take the open d-file with my rook...
moves.17... Rd2: ...and I bring it up to attack on the 7th rank...
moves.19. c4 Rxa2: ...but what was I thinking removing another...
moves.20. Nc3: ...and allowing my knight to fork my rook and bishop?
moves.20... Rxg2+: However, I remove a third pawn...
moves.22... a6: Now I move up my right flank pawn to prevent his knight from forking two pawns...
moves.23. Nd5: ...so his knight attacks my c-pawn form the other side...
moves.23... Rc8: ...forcing my rook into a passive position.
moves.24. Rf1+: As my king is attacked by the rook...
moves.24... Ke6: ...I move my king up to pressure the centre.
moves.25. Rb1: His rook eyes up my b-pawn...
moves.26. Nc3 Nxc4: ...and I take a huge risk, removing his c-pawn...
moves.27... Nd2+: ...allows me to perform one final knight fork.
